results.title: Other olympics
results.creator_credit: Don Worley, Kevin Boulton and ABC
results.brief_description: A look at the 1980 Olympics for the disabled held in Arnhem, Netherlands because Moscow declined the offer to stage the event, in which thousands of handicapped people competed in a wide range of events. The first Disabled games was held in London 1948, only 16 competetors, 1960 in Rome - 400 competetors, but, in 1980 over 42 countries competed. The partcipants included paraplegics, quadraplegics, amputees, people who have cerebal palsey, polio and varying degrees of blindness. It was at these games that users and wheelchair designers explored and exhibited new designs to assist the handicapped. H.R.H.Princess Margaritte opened the games which had the ideals of friendship, unity and sportsmanship. Many world records were broken. This program was narrated by Richard Morecroft.

results.title: Jane Fonda
results.creator_credit: Michael Barnes and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: A documentary about Jane Fonda, her family, social and political activities and her own account of how she came to break with her Hollywood background. Focuses on the contradictions and controversies which she has had to resolve in her private life and in her career as an actress.

results.title: Jimmy the C
results.creator_credit: Jimmy Picker, Jimmy the C Productions and Motionpicker Studios
results.brief_description: Animated film in which a clay Jimmy Carter (using the voice of Ray Charles) evokes the simpler days prior to his Presidency by singing “Georgia on my mind”, flanked by an American flag and backed by a trio of top-hatted peanuts.

results.title: Night on Bald Mountain = Nuit sur le Mont Chauve
results.brief_description: A significant early animation from the silent/sound transition period, this fantasy is based on Mussorgsky’s tone (symphonic) poem, evoking a world of demons, witches and goblins. The first film by the Parisian lithographer, Alexander Alexeieff (made with the assistance of his wife Claire Parker) using his famous pinboard invention which allowed production of a great range of tonal qualities.

results.title: The Field mouse
results.creator_credit: Steve Helling and Scandinavian Videocassette Group
results.brief_description: The life cycle, habits and characteristics of the field mouse are shown in the context of its ecosystem. Highlights factors such as food availability, predators, population levels and adaptive behaviour. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Fastest animal on earth
results.creator_credit: George Lindsay, FilmFair Communications and George Linsay Film Productions
results.brief_description: Gives basic facts about the cheetah, including its habits, unique physical characteristics and historicl significance. Shows cheetahs in their natural environment where their greatest enemy is man. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Genetic chance
results.creator_credit: Robert Reid and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “My Children My Children”.
Examines the moral and social implications of determining genetic disorders in unborn infants, and looks at the effects of a number of such disorders. Most of the discussion is centred around haemophilia.

results.title: The Formula factor
results.creator_credit: Rosalind Farber and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”.
Documents the problems and dangers of infant formula marketing and bottle-feeding in the third world. Highlights the efforts of government health workers and church organisations to challenge the practices of multinational corporations who are irresponsible and somewhat aggressive in their promotion of formula and their chase for profits. Focuses on Nestles, the world’s largest producer of baby formula. Presented by Roy Bonisteel. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.
